msgSnippet: ... Along in time, and not necessarily along in space. (In other words, at the same time, yes; but in the same file, no.) ... I don t think it is. A test
messageBody:

>
>
> "Chappell, Simon P" <simon.chappell@...> wrote:
> >-----Original Message-----

> >Subject: Re: [junit] test with in
>
> <snip>
>
> >I will add this important point: one of the nice things about xUnit
> >(JUnit included) is that we write the tests in the same
> >language as the
> >production code. Your approach breaks this model for no apparent gain.
> >(Tell us why you prefer to do what you propose over just writing JUnit
> >tests in the usual way.)
>
> Nice catch J.B., I hadn't thought of that one. I'll add it to my mental
> checklist for this type of question. Perhaps Mike could add this to the FAQ.
>
> Some points I have considered were
>
> .To write test along with the main code logic

"Along" in time, and not necessarily "along" in space. (In other words,
at the same time, yes; but in the same file, no.)

> .Testing (Some what Validation of Code) is perhaps the property of the
> Component we are coding for and therefor containd within.

I don't think it is. A test is just another piece of client code, and
clients do not belong to providers!

> .Well why should i compile the code if it doesnot seems to be wroking So
> assuring it to work while it is build.

This is interesting. I would recommend using the Zero Button Testing
package for Eclipse, rather than your approach. I /really/ liked it when
I tried it.

Take care.
